text.author: Wikinews
text.title: Texas student Ahmed Mohamed inspires social movement
text.summary1: (human1) Ahmed Mohamed, a 14 year old muslim boy from Irving, Texas, was wrongfully arrested at school on September 14, 2015 by local police after a digital clock he had built was mistaken for a bomb, sparking protests on social media and leading to invitations for Ahmed to visit the White House, U.N. headquarters in New York, Facebook and Google Science Fair.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) 14-year-old Ahmed Mohamed's wrongful arrest for bringing a homemade digital clock to his Texas school sparked a global social movement, earning him support from President Obama and tech leaders, and invitations to the White House, Google, and UN.
text.summary3: (gpt4o) The arrest of 14-year-old Ahmed Mohamed for bringing a homemade clock to school, mistaken as a bomb, sparked a global movement. Influential figures like President Obama and Mark Zuckerberg supported him, highlighting race and Islamophobia issues. Mohamed received invitations to events like the Google Science Fair and a UN meeting.
text.summary4: (Llama-3.2-3B-Instruct) Ahmed Mohamed, a 14-year-old boy from Texas, was arrested and questioned by police after bringing a digital clock he made to school, but his case has sparked a global social movement in support of him, with many notable figures and organizations expressing their support and solidarity.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) A 14-year-old boy named Ahmed Mohamed faced arrest after bringing a homemade clock to school, but gained widespread support leading to meetings with tech leaders, the President of the United States, and international dignitaries. #IStandWithAhmed
